The Trump administration has tightened enforcement of immigration-related rules. Above, immigration agents serve an employment audit notice at a 7-Eleven convenience store in Los Angeles in January. Associated Press Good morning. Many U.S. employers began last year full of hope a more business-friendly Trump administration would roll back Obama-era workplace rules. Some of those changes came to pass but the shift in direction came at a price, as 64% of respondents to a survey said the changes in workplace policies and regulations created a burden for their businesses.
And policy moves by state and local governments in response to federal actions have complicated matters still more, according to the survey of 1,111 in-house lawyers, human-resources people and C-suite executives by law firm Littler Mendelson PC. Three-quarters of respondents said these employment-related state and local requirements led to compliance challenges.
Policies related to health-care law, overtime, unionization and the collection of data on pay were dropped or put on hold while the Trump administration tightened regulation on immigration, Littler said. “Employers have justifiably felt buffeted by abrupt and sweeping regulatory changes as policies are built and, often while workplaces are still adapting to them, dismantled,” the firm said.
Employers expect less drama in the coming 12 months, the survey found. Fifteen percent expect a major impact from the Affordable Care Act in 2018, compared with 33% in 2017. The share of respondents concerned about enforcement by the Department of Labor slid to 16% from 25%, while worry over action by the National Labor Relations Board fell to 8% from 13%.
“Companies want certainty more than anything,” said Michael Lotito, co-chairman of Littler’s Workplace Policy Institute. “Uncertainty means inability to plan, budget and anticipate, and it requires constantly retraining employees and reformulating employment policies.”
COMPLIANCE
VW ex-chief is indicted over emissions. Volkswagen AG ’s former chief executive, Martin Winterkorn , faces U.S. charges for his alleged role in an emissions scandal that has cost the German auto giant billions of dollars in penalties, the WSJ reports. An attorney for Mr. Winterkorn said he would make a statement at an appropriate time.
Former Volkswagen CEO Martin Winterkorn in Brunswick, Germany, in January. PHOTO: JOHN MACDOUGALL/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE/GETTY IMAGES Ex-trader’s conviction is tossed out. A U.S. appeals court vacated the conviction of former Jefferies Group LLC trader Jesse Litvak. Mr. Litvak had been convicted of securities fraud related to the sale of mortgage-backed debt. The court found a lower court “materially erred” in allowing the admission of certain evidence, the WSJ reports.
Ex-Wilmington Trust executives are convicted. Four former executives for Wilmington Trust , the only financial institution to be criminally charged in connection with the U.S. federal bank-bailout program were convicted Thursday on fraud and conspiracy charges, the AP reports.
Brazil targets laundering ring. Brazilian prosecutors issued arrest warrants for 53 people, most of them black-market money changers, as they took aim against a money-laundering rings, Reuters reports.
DATA SECURITY
Twitter urges users to change passwords. Twitter Inc. on Thursday said it found a bug in how it stored user passwords that could have left them visible to people in its internal computer system.Twitter urged its users to change their passwords, but said an investigation showed no indication of a breach, the WSJ reports.
GOVERNANCE
Xerox chief to remain, after all. Two days after reaching an agreement with activist investors Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason to oust its chief executive and revamp its board, Xerox Corp. said they instead would stay in place after the deal expired without certain conditions being met, the WSJ reports.
Equifax directors win re-election . Equifax shareholders voted to re-elect all of the company’s board members who were on the ballot, though several received a significant number of “no” votes. It was the first annual shareholder meeting since the firm disclosed a major data breach last September, the WSJ reports.
Board-seat fight at Telecom Italia. Telecom Italia ’s top two investors will put their battle over board seats at the Italian phone group to a shareholder vote on Friday. Elliott Management , with 9%, and Vivendi , with 24%, have been sparring for two months, Reuters reports.
REPUTATION
Congressman denies sex-assault allegations. Democratic Rep. Tony Cárdenas has acknowledged that he is the anonymous politician named in a lawsuit in Los Angeles county court alleging sexual assault and battery against a minor, but said through an attorney that he is innocent, the WSJ reports.
No Nobel prize in literature this year. The Swedish Academy, the institution responsible for awarding the Nobel Prize in Literature, said Friday it won’t name a winner this year to take the time to repair the damage from a protracted scandal over allegations of sexual assault and financial impropriety, the WSJ reports.
Nike CEO apologizes to staff. Nike Inc. Chief Executive Mark Parker apologized to employees Thursday for allowing a corporate culture that excluded some staff and failed to take seriously complaints about workplace issues, the WSJ reports. A rare all-staff meeting followed weeks of turmoil.
EY settles sexual-misconduct complaint. Ernst & Young LLP has reached a confidential settlement with a tax partner who alleged that another EY company partner sexually harassed and assaulted her in 2015 and that the firm didn’t take the matter seriously, the WSJ reports.
RISK
Trade fight hits U.S. commodity sales. The U.S.-China trade spat is cutting into exports of U.S. farm commodities. Since early April, Chinese importers have canceled purchases of corn and cut orders for pork while dramatically reducing new soybean purchases, according to U.S. Department of Agriculture data, the WSJ reports.
GE warns of potential bankruptcy for subprime unit. General Electric Co. warned it might put its dormant subprime mortgage business, plagued by legal trouble, into bankruptcy protection. That could help WMC Mortgage deal with potential courtroom losses and other future liabilities, GE said in a securities filing Tuesday, the WSJ reports.
OPERATIONS
Volcano erupts in Hawaii. The Kilauea volcano erupted on Hawaii’s Big Island on Thursday, prompting local authorities to issue mandatory evacuations for more than 1,500 residents as an active lava flow threatened homes. Gov. David Ige declared a state of emergency, the WSJ reports.
STRATEGY
Norwegian airline rejects IAG bid. Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA has rebuffed a takeover bid by British Airways parent IAG, as the battle for the trans-Atlantic market intensifies. International Consolidated Airlines Group said Friday it had made a takeover offer, after disclosing in April a 4.61% stake in the Scandinavian carrier, the WSJ reports.
Norwegian Air Shuttle CEO Bjørn Kjos speaks in Buenos Aires at the launch of the company’s trans-Atlantic flight service from Argentina, on March 8.
